author: By Natalie Kitroeff
title: ‘We Are Not Equipped to Deal With This’: Migrant Surge Overwhelms U.S. Border
description: Officials are struggling to contend with the chaos at the U.S.-Mexico border as thousands of migrants arrive every day, trekking from the farthest reaches of the globe.
content: At a remote spot in the Arizona desert, near a hole in the border wall, dozens of migrants huddled over wood fires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Is This the Endgame for the Age of Heroes?
description: Audiences are showing fatigue when it comes to Marvel’s box office behemoths of recent years. Based on what they were served in 2023, it’s hard to blame them.
content: At the center of 2023’s “The Marvels” is Carol Danvers, a.k.a. Captain Marvel, who, if you’ll recall from the 2019 film “Captain Marvel,” destroyed the all-powerful A.I. leading the Kree empire. Joining Carol Danvers is Monica Rambeau, a.k.a. Photon a.k.a. Pulsar a.k.a. Spectrum, who was first introduced in “Captain Marvel,” then later featured in the Disney+ series “WandaVision,” where she was granted superpowers after an encounter with reality-altering witches. And joining these two Marvels is the teenage New Jersey native Kamala Khan, a.k.a. the titular character of the Disney+ series “Ms. Marvel.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson and Liset Cruz
title: Shelter Evictions Will Damage Migrant Children, Schools Warn
description: About 3,500 migrant families in New York City shelters have received eviction notices. Children will have to change schools or face long commutes.
content: Since last summer, tens of thousands of migrant families living in homeless shelters have enrolled children in New York City schools. Their arrival buoyed the system, which had been losing students, prompting the mayor to declare that “public schools are back.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Powerful Realtors Group Loses Its Grip on the Industry
description: The National Association of Realtors is facing antitrust lawsuits and sexual harassment allegations, and real estate agents are now looking for alternatives.
content: The staff members of the National Association of Realtors, the largest professional organization in the United States, were in a panic. Two days before the group’s national convention, they had set up 400 exhibition booths and were expecting nearly 12,000 people to arrive for three days of speakers, training sessions and networking.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Rusted or Mended With Love, Beetles Are Part of the Family
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, December 27, 2023.
content: “It is not a standard car like any other.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Liu
title: Will China Ease Its New Video Game Controls? Investors Think So.
description: After a market rout, gaming companies like Tencent and Netease rallied on signals that regulators might apply proposed curbs on users less harshly than feared.
content: The stock prices of Chinese video game companies rebounded Wednesday after investors seized on signals that the government was having second thoughts about proposed regulations on gaming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: This Silly Museum About Crabs Has Serious Things to Say
description: The tiny Crab Museum in Margate, England, is gaining attention for its irreverent crustacean exhibits that also teach visitors about climate change and capitalism.
content: At the Crab Museum in the seaside town of Margate, England, Tereza Hynkova, 24, stopped in front of a display case, and started to giggle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John White, Larissa Anderson and Diane Wong
title: The Best Movie of 2023
description: Our chief film critic picks her favorite film of the year.
content: Chief film critic Manohla Dargis watched hundreds of films this year, and reviewed dozens. She believes she has seen a masterpiece, Martin Scorsese’s “Killers of the Flower Moon.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner and Thomas Fuller
title: Israel Will Not Soon End Its War With Hamas, Officials Say
description: Amid global pressure to reach a cease-fire and fears of a widening regional war, Israel says it will continue to fight in Gaza until Hamas is defeated.
content: Israel insisted on Tuesday that its war in Gaza would not end soon and pledged to complete its mission of dismantling Hamas no matter how long it took, despite widespread international calls for a cease-fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim
title: A Fake Trump Elector in Michigan Told Prosecutors of Regret, Anger
description: The Trump supporter is the only one of the 16 fake Michigan electors who has agreed to cooperate with the authorities and had charges against him dropped.
content: One of the Republicans in Michigan who acted as a fake elector for Donald J. Trump expressed deep regret about his participation, according to a recording of his interview with the state attorney general’s office that was obtained by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yiwen Lu
title: Intel Moves Forward With $25 Billion Chip Plant Expansion in Israel
description: The plan, which was disclosed without details before the Israel-Hamas war, would create thousands of jobs and begin operations by 2028.
content: The semiconductor giant Intel confirmed on Wednesday that it would invest $25 billion to expand a chip factory in southern Israel after a $3.2 billion grant from the government there, moving ahead with a major investment in a country currently at war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: The Great 2023 Streaming Movies You May Have Missed
description: This collection of gems includes character-driven dramas, dark comedies, smart documentaries, and romantic comedies both sunny and disturbing.
content: As 2023 comes to a close, our monthly showcase of hidden gems on your streaming subscription services showcases a handful of worthwhile releases from this year that may have escaped your notice: character-driven dramas, dark comedies, smart documentaries, and romantic comedies both sunny and disturbing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Blue Material
description: Kareem Ayas makes his New York Times debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: Indian Envoy Meets With Putin, Bypassing Western Pressure
description: India’s foreign minister is on a five-day diplomatic trip to Moscow to reinforce economic and defense ties, though some strains in the countries’ relationship are showing.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin on Wednesday met with the Indian foreign minister at the Kremlin, highlighting Russia’s attempts to break through its isolation from the West by pivoting to an increasingly powerful Asian nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: Shipping Giant Maersk Is Returning to the Red Sea After Houthi Attacks
description: A shipping advisory that Maersk released on Wednesday showed that several of its vessels were headed for the Suez Canal, which lies at the northern end of the Red Sea and handles about 12 percent of world trade.
content: The shipping giant Maersk indicated on Wednesday that after avoiding the Red Sea and the Suez Canal for about a week because of attacks on shipping it was again directing its vessels through the canal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Thursday Briefing: Chinese Spies Compete With U.S. Spies
description: Also, the death of a Korean actor and food predictions for 2024.
content: China’s Ministry of State Security is deploying artificial intelligence and other advanced technology to compete with the C.I.A. At the same time, the C.I.A. is pouring resources into monitoring Chinese companies that are developing A.I., quantum computing and other such tools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Skepticism Grows Over Israel’s Ability to Dismantle Hamas
description: Israel has vowed time and again to eliminate the group responsible for the brutal Oct. 7 attack, but critics increasingly see that goal as unrealistic or even impossible.
content: Standing before a gray backdrop decorated with Hamas logos and emblems of a gunman that commemorate the bloody Oct. 7 attack on Israel, Osama Hamdan, the organization’s representative in Lebanon, professed no concern about his Palestinian faction being dislodged from Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Love a TV Show? Now You Can Live It.
description: Streamers and networks are creating live experiences to promote series like “Squid Game” and “Only Murders in the Building.” But do they amount to anything more than just marketing?
content: On a sun-nuzzled morning in Los Angeles, 25 people filed into a narrow, windowless room. They were about to participate in “Squid Game: The Trials,” an interactive experience based on the popular, dystopian Netflix franchise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Country Music’s Outrage Head Fake
description: A few weeks of political brouhaha this summer obscured a different story: The genre is moving, in fits and starts, from the political to the personal.
content: For a spell this summer, it appeared as if Nashville was headed toward another season of polarization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: I Offered to Give My Home to My Son. Why Does He Expect Me to Leave It?
description: After her son responded with interest to the idea of moving back home to raise a family, a mother is hurt to realize that he never intended to keep her around.
content: I am 68 and live alone in a nice home in the suburbs. My only child, 40, is happily settled with his fiancée in another city. I always hoped they would come back here to raise a family, and I offered to give them my home if they did. They like the idea and plan to build a new house on the site. Over Christmas, I told them I was excited about their plan and added: “You could build a mother-in-law apartment for me or even a guesthouse.” It’s a large lot. My son burst out laughing and said, “Mom, you wouldn’t live with us.” They assumed I would move into a condo. I was shattered! The next day, he said he was sorry if I felt they were kicking me out of my house. I do. I also think if I don’t go along with them, they will stay where they are. Advice?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius and Olivia Bensimon
title: Man Accused in Grand Central Stabbing Had Repeated Run-Ins With Police
description: Steven Hutcherson’s ex-girlfriend said she had repeatedly called 911 about him and had reported his mental condition to the authorities.
content: The man who stabbed two teenage sisters in Grand Central Terminal on Christmas Day had encountered the police at least 15 times this year, frightened his ex-girlfriend’s family into seeking a restraining order and recently was taken to a Bronx hospital for psychological evaluation, Police Department records show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Heller and Miguel Salazar
title: The Fine Art of the Paperback Makeover
description: Redesign? Relaunch? Regret? Take a look at the ways publishers aimed to seduce new audiences by changing up the covers of notable books.
content: “You never get a second chance to make a first impression,” the humorist Will Rogers once said — which tells you he wasn’t a book publishing executive. In that world, the paperback edition is the second chance, an opportunity to market a book at a lower price and, in many cases, with new cover imagery aimed at new audiences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Chouinard
title: Ladle Me a Bowl of the Midwestern Good Stuff
description: My pursuit of culinary knowledge became an escape from the mundane, the provincial, the working class.
content: I was not raised in a family of cooks. My parents grew up in the Midwest, in the second half of the last century, during a period in which a great deal of culinary knowledge was lost. Our signature meals came out of cardboard or cellophane or, most often, some combination of the two. My dad who, for the region, is something of an epicure, loved to “spice up” boxed holiday stuffing by tossing it with lightly sautéed onions and peppers. My mom took many a weekday dinner out of the chest freezer in the basement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Gaston Glock, Inventor of the Gun That Bears His Name, Dies at 94
description: A reclusive Austrian billionaire, he created the handgun worn by two-thirds of America’s police officers and the security forces of at least 48 countries.
content: Gaston Glock, the Austrian engineer who invented the boxy Glock handgun, which has become a weapon of choice for national security forces, law enforcement officials, violent criminals and gun enthusiasts in America and around the world, died on Wednesday. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: Why Parents Give Their Children a Last Name Other Than the Father’s
description: Some American parents have been breaking the patrilineal tradition for generations, but the number who do so remains small.
content: When Judy Pellarin had her daughters three decades ago, she and her husband gave them her last name instead of his. A generation later, her daughters also broke tradition — one gave her daughter her surname, and the other created a new name, a blending of her and her husband’s middle names.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: A Crybaby Year for Men in the Movies
description: In 2023, male characters pouted elaborately after something they saw as their birthright was put in check.
content: I’ve seen the greatest men of my generation regress into petulant babies — at least in the movies. Over and over in this year’s films, male characters throw elaborate temper tantrums, whining, huffing and raging like toddlers in their terrible twos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: She’s Still in Love With Her Little Island
description: Readers were impressed with the audacity of Charlotte Gale, a massage therapist from New Jersey, who bought a small island in Maine.
content: “I think I learned all the different types of fog,” said Charlotte Gale, describing her first full summer as owner and sole resident of Duck Ledges Island, the one-and-a-half-acre rocky outcropping complete with tiny cabin that she bought last year in Downeast Maine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: True-Crime Podcasts About Trump Are Everywhere
description: MSNBC, NPR, Vox Media and The Atlanta Journal-Constitution are all aiming to capitalize on interest in the criminal cases against President Donald J. Trump with the shows.
content: True crime is among the most popular genres in podcasting. One of the biggest stories in the coming months is the wave of criminal charges facing former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: A Private Liberal Arts College Is Drowning in Debt. Should Alabama Rescue It?
description: Birmingham-Southern College was on the verge of receiving a multimillion-dollar loan, but the state treasurer balked, saying it was not a justifiable use of taxpayer money.
content: On a crisp fall day at Birmingham-Southern College, the students were making their way to class, stealing a few cold minutes under the golden ginkgo trees. Inside the red brick buildings that dot the 192-acre campus, professors were preparing exams for finals week, while administrators readied the first round of acceptance letters for the next school year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Abrams and Rawan Sheikh Ahmad
title: Israeli Raid on West Bank Refugee Camp Kills 6, Palestinians Say
description: The Israeli military said that its forces had carried out a counterterrorism operation overnight in the Nur Shams refugee camp.
content: An Israeli raid on a refugee camp in the occupied West Bank has left six Palestinians dead, the Palestinian Authority’s Ministry of Health said on Wednesday. They were the latest casualties in a surge of violence in the territory since the war in Gaza began on Oct. 7.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Death by Doctor May Soon Be Available for the Mentally Ill in Canada
description: The country is divided over a law that would allow patients suffering from mental health illnesses to apply for assisted death.
content: Canada already has one of the most liberal assisted death laws in the world, offering the practice to terminally and chronically ill Canadians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Colorado Republican Party Says It Asked Supreme Court to Keep Trump on Ballot
description: The party’s petition urged the justices to review a ruling from the Colorado Supreme Court, which said the former president had engaged in insurrection and is ineligible to hold office.
content: The Colorado Republican Party said it had asked the U.S. Supreme Court on Wednesday to hear an appeal of the bombshell decision from the Colorado Supreme Court ordering former President Donald J. Trump’s removal from the state’s primary ballot. The state court ruled that he was ineligible to hold office because he had engaged in insurrection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Man Charged With Hate Crimes in Stabbing of 2 Teens at Grand Central
description: Esteban Esono-Asue uttered an anti-white slur before attacking two sisters from Paraguay who were on a family trip to New York, officials said.
content: A Bronx man faces charges of attempted murder and assault as hate crimes after using an anti-white slur before stabbing two teenage sisters at a restaurant in Grand Central Terminal on Christmas Day, according to officials and court records.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zeynep Tufekci
title: Avert Your Eyes, Avoid Responsibility and Just Blame TikTok
description: Blaming social media for all kinds of social ills is more convenient to politicians than turning their shared anger into sensible legislation.
content: We’re in a season of hand-wringing and scapegoating over social media, especially TikTok, with many Americans and politicians missing that two things can be true at once: Social media can have an outsize and sometimes pernicious influence on society, and lawmakers can unfairly use it as an excuse to deflect legitimate criticisms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
title: Jiang Ping, the ‘Conscience of China’s Legal World,’ Dies at 92
description: He was removed from his university presidency after supporting pro-democracy protesters at Tiananmen Square. He remained a relentless advocate for rule of law.
content: Jiang Ping, a legal scholar who helped lay the foundation for China’s civil code, and whose experiences with political persecution shaped his relentless advocacy for individual rights in the face of state power, died on Dec. 19 in Beijing. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Ryan Mac
title: The Times Sues OpenAI and Microsoft Over A.I. Use of Copyrighted Work
description: Millions of articles from The New York Times were used to train chatbots that now compete with it, the lawsuit said.
content: The New York Times sued OpenAI and Microsoft for copyright infringement on Wednesday, opening a new front in the increasingly intense legal battle over the unauthorized use of published work to train artificial intelligence technologies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: House Republicans Target Biden by Focusing on His Son’s News Conference
description: Two leaders of the impeachment inquiry into President Biden say they are investigating whether he was involved in Hunter Biden’s decision to defy a congressional subpoena.
content: House Republicans said Wednesday they were investigating whether President Biden was involved in his son Hunter Biden’s decision to defy a congressional subpoena in their latest attempt to link the White House to accusations against the president’s son.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Helping a Child Navigate Grief? Open a Picture Book.
description: When “I’m sorry for your loss” isn’t going to cut it, young readers might find solace, and solidarity, in story time.
content: “But where did he go?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: The Factors That Made Evangelicals Ready for Trump
description: What primed some evangelical Christians to think in apocalyptic terms about America? Jane Coaston interviews Tim Alberta about Donald Trump, Covid and Christianity.
content: Roughly 24 percent of Americans consider themselves “born-again or evangelical,” but what that means — spiritually, culturally, politically — depends on whom you ask. For some evangelicals, the role of politics, particularly the politics of today’s Republican Party, has taken on deep importance, changing how they relate to their faith, their faith leadership and one another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman, Ernesto Londoño and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Michigan Supreme Court Decides Trump Can Stay on Ballot
description: After Colorado’s top court ruled that the former president was disqualified for engaging in insurrection, justices in Michigan considered a similar challenge.
content: The Michigan Supreme Court on Wednesday gave Donald J. Trump an important victory in the legal battle over his eligibility to return to the White House by allowing the former president to appear on the state’s primary ballot in February.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nadav Gavrielov and Safak Timur
title: Erdogan Compares Netanyahu to Hitler
description: The Turkish leader has lashed out at the Israeli prime minister multiple times since the start of the war in Gaza.
content: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel exchanged sharp words on Wednesday after Mr. Erdogan compared the Israeli leader to Adolf Hitler while discussing Israel’s war in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Biden Begins Weeklong Vacation in Caribbean to Ring in the New Year
description: But work has a way of intruding on even the most secluded getaways, especially if you’re the commander in chief.
content: President Biden left the drizzly skies of Washington behind on Wednesday and flew to tropical St. Croix in the U.S. Virgin Islands, where he and Jill Biden, the first lady, intend to ring in the new year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Tobias
title: ‘Fargo’ Season 5, Episode 7: Not Your Puppet
description: Gator takes matters into his own hands. Dot takes a drive. Wayne takes a trade-in.
content: After eight episodes of frolicking in a Coen-ized version of gangland Kansas City in the early 1950s, the last season of “Fargo” shifted audaciously to a black-and-white homage to “The Wizard of Oz,” complete with a tornado as deus ex machina. Having already moved the show out of the Coens’ Minnesota and North Dakota, its creator, Noah Hawley, gave himself the license to claim another patch of Heartland terrain, as if advancing across a Risk board. The Coens had ended “A Serious Man” with a tornado, too, so it wasn’t even that off brand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: New Year’s Eve in New York: What to Do, See and Eat
description: Dance parties, cabaret shows, midnight runs and, of course, the Times Square ball drop: our guide to ringing in the new year in the city.
content: Whether you want to brave the crowds or beat them, here’s a guide to New Year’s Eve parties, shows, family-friendly events and other festivities in the New York area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Nikki Haley’s Bold Strategy to Beat Trump: Play It Safe
description: Ms. Haley still trails far behind the former president in polls. Yet she is not deviating from the cautious approach that has led her this far.
content: At a packed community center in southwestern Iowa, Nikki Haley broke from her usual remarks this month to offer a warning to her top Republican presidential rivals, Donald J. Trump and Ron DeSantis, deploying a favorite line: “If they punch me, I punch back — and I punch back harder.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Plagiarism Allegations Against Claudine Gay
description: Readers discuss an investigation into Harvard’s president. Also: The Bronx Defenders; undoing Roe v. Wade; buying cashmere.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Glatsky
title: A Statue’s Hips Don’t Lie: Shakira Is Honored in Her Hometown
description: A (tall) statue of the Colombian singer was unveiled this week along the waterfront in Barranquilla, the city where she grew up.
content: The Colombian coastal city of Barranquilla this week revealed a 21-foot-tall tribute to one of the country’s most famous cultural exports: Shakira.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Clare Toeniskoetter, Will Reid, Mooj Zadie, Alex Stern, Michael Benoist, Patricia Willens, Elisheba Ittoop, Diane Wong, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Chris Wood and Alyssa Moxley
title: Inside Russia’s Crackdown on Dissent: An Update
description: How a social media post landed a 19-year-old student on the Kremlin’s official terrorist list.
content: This week, The Daily is revisiting some of our favorite episodes of the year and checking in on what has happened in the time since they first ran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Vance
title: 12 Workouts to Try in 2024
description: Here are some of our favorite moves to help you feel strong and age well, no matter your fitness level.
content: Finding a reliable, enjoyable way to stay fit can be a bit overwhelming. Should you do Crossfit, Pilates or pickleball? Is Zumba still a thing? Does running to catch the bus count as exercise?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Tesla Strike Is a Culture Clash: Swedish Labor vs. American Management
description: Workers seeking a collective agreement from the automaker say they are pushing for their rights, but car owners see them as taking the fight too far.
content: The Tesla technicians who walked off their jobs in Sweden say they still support the mission of the American company and its headline-grabbing chief executive. But they also want Tesla to accept the Swedish way of doing business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser and Amanda Holpuch
title: Michael Flynn’s Rhode Island Hall of Fame Inclusion Prompts Resignations
description: At least five board members resigned and said that Michael T. Flynn, the former national security adviser for President Trump, should not be recognized.
content: At least five board members who oversee the Rhode Island Heritage Hall of Fame have resigned from the organization after Michael T. Flynn, the former national security adviser under Donald J. Trump, was chosen to be inducted in 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Storms in Australia Leave at Least 9 Dead
description: Extreme weather in the eastern states of Queensland and Victoria this week knocked out power for tens of thousands of residents, the authorities said.
content: At least nine people were found dead in Australia after storms and floods in the eastern part of the country caused power outages and damaged infrastructure over the Christmas holiday period, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: For a Times Critic on Deadline, a Dramatic Reversal
description: Stories evolve. But a recent review proved to a theater critic that people can change even more.
content: I wasn’t sure whether I wanted to do my job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2 Million Homes in Connecticut, New Jersey and New Mexico
description: A 1707 Colonial in Westport, an 1879 Victorian in Ocean Grove and a three-bedroom home in Santa Fe.
content: While this Fairfield County home has been expanded since it was constructed in the early 18th century, the owners have taken care to preserve and even augment its character: An early 1990s addition, for example, was built using repurposed materials from a circa 1850 home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Grimes
title: Tom Smothers, Comic Half of the Smothers Brothers, Dies at 86
description: Though he played a naïve buffoon onstage, he was the driving force behind the folk-singing duo’s groundbreaking TV show.
content: Tom Smothers, the older half of the comic folk duo the Smothers Brothers, whose skits and songs on “The Smothers Brothers Comedy Hour” in the late 1960s brought political satire and a spirit of youthful irreverence to network television, paving the way for shows like “Saturday Night Live” and “The Daily Show,” died on Tuesday at his home in Santa Rosa, Calif., a city in Sonoma County. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Trump Assails Congresswoman in His Latest Escalation on Social Media
description: The former president, who has stepped up his incendiary language on Truth Social, attacked Representative Debbie Dingell, the widow of John D. Dingell Jr.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump on Tuesday fired off a new attack against Representative Debbie Dingell, the widow of John D. Dingell Jr., the longest-serving member of Congress in American history, calling her a “loser” and suggesting that she had not been grateful for funeral honors granted by Mr. Trump for her husband.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts
title: Idaho Judge Temporarily Blocks Ban on Gender Transition Care for Minors
description: Transgender minors in the state will be able to receive gender transition care for now, while the challenge against the state ban proceeds.
content: A federal judge in Idaho temporarily blocked the enforcement of a state law on Tuesday that bans gender transition care for minors and threatens medical professionals with a felony conviction if they provide such care, just six days before it was set to take effect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: A ‘Fabulous’ Chicken Stew That’s ‘Heaven’
description: This creamy spinach-artichoke chicken stew boasts five stars, rave reviews and — crucially — a jar of marinated artichoke hearts.
content: Hi there! Mia here, your trusty New York Times Cooking newsletter editor. I’m filling in for Melissa today and for Sam on Friday while they’re on vacation, and I’m chock-full of cookies — specifically the giant choco chunkies from Samantha Seneviratne’s new cookbook — and sparkling apple cider. Let’s do this!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman, Natan Odenheimer and Ronen Bergman
title: A General’s Account of Oct. 7 Battle for Be’eri Stirs Debate in Israel
description: The commander told The New York Times about how he had authorized Israeli tank fire on a house where hostages were being held by Hamas fighters.
content: The Israeli military said it would review the circumstances of an Oct. 7 battle to retake a village from Hamas fighters, after a New York Times investigation featuring new details about Israeli tank fire on a house where hostages were being held stirred debate in Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivienne Walt
title: What’s Next in Artificial Intelligence?
description: If 2023 was the year of A.I. awakening, 2024 could be the year of A.I. reckoning.
content: Mustafa Suleyman remembers the epochal moment he grasped artificial intelligence’s potential. It was 2016 — Paleolithic times by A.I. standards — and DeepMind, the company he had co-founded that was acquired by Google in 2014, had pitted its A.I. machine, AlphaGo, against a world champion of Go, the confoundingly difficult strategy game. AlphaGo zipped through thousands of permutations, making fast work of the hapless human. Stunned, Suleyman realized the machine had “seemingly superhuman insights,” he says in his  book on A.I., “The Coming Wave.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: Israel predicts “many more months” of war.
content: Israel is focusing its military efforts in the southern region of Gaza and expects the war to continue for “many more months,” Lt. Gen. Herzi Halevi, the Israeli military chief of staff, said. More than 1.7 million displaced Gazans are registered in shelters in the south, including many who are sleeping along roads and in open spaces. Food and water are scarce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Cowell
title: Wolfgang Schäuble, German Politician Who Helped Forge European Unity, Dies at 81
description: An important figure in the reunification of East and West Germany, he played a key role in shaping German politics for decades and was once seen as a likely chancellor.
content: Wolfgang Schäuble, who was among the most influential and combative political figures in postwar West Germany, and who played central roles in his country’s reunification with the Communist east and in its subsequent projection of economic might, died on Tuesday. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamed Aleaziz and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
title: Blinken Meets With Mexico’s President About Surge in Migration at the Border
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken’s meeting with President Andrés Manuel López Obrador comes as border crossings have reached record numbers and as a migrant caravan heads toward the United States.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and other top American officials discussed the root causes of migration with Mexico’s president on Wednesday in hopes of figuring out a strategy to slow the surge in illegal crossings at the southern U.S. border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nadav Gavrielov
title: Hamas and Other Militant Groups Are Firing Rockets Into Israel Every Day
description: Israel says some 12,000 rockets have been fired from Gaza starting on Oct. 7. They have killed 15 people in Israel.
content: As Israel wages a war in Gaza aimed at dismantling Hamas’s military capacity, the armed group and its affiliates have continued to fire rockets at Israel nearly every day, aiming deep inside its borders and striking some of the country’s biggest cities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anusha Bayya
title: Board Game Cafe Workers Went on a Quest for a Union and Won
description: “There is not a group of people better at organizing than a bunch of nerds,” said a worker at one of New York City’s cafes catering to the Dungeons & Dragons crowd.
content: A golden glow illuminated the employees huddled inside a Hex & Co. cafe on the Upper East Side, a haven created for board game enthusiasts to gather for fantastical quests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: The Best and Worst (and Dumbest) From 6 Seasons of ‘The Crown’
description: As the Netflix series depicting the royal family concludes, it’s time to hand out some superlatives.
content: “The Crown” has been a dizzying marathon of a series, packing nearly 60 years of history into six seasons of serious drama and frivolous gossip. Sometimes rushing headlong through the decades, other times plodding turgidly through the minutes, the show has been destination television since 2016 — a sumptuous, low-stakes diversion in an era of bewildering turmoil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bob Bauer and Jack Goldsmith
title: Trump Is Not the Only Reason to Fix This Uniquely Dangerous Law
description: Democrats and Republicans should both want to deny any president unchecked authority to use the military in the homeland.
content: The Insurrection Act is a dangerous centuries-old federal statute that authorizes the president, with few restraints, to deploy the U.S. military inside the United States to suppress threats the president perceives to the constitutional order. Commentators have recently proposed tightening the law following reports that former President Donald Trump and his advisers are planning to use it aggressively for law enforcement and to quell domestic disturbances if Mr. Trump is once more elected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays and Dana Rubinstein
title: In Bid to Slow Migrant Surge, Adams Restricts Bus Arrivals Into New York
description: In an executive order, Mayor Eric Adams required bus companies to provide advance notice of trips or face criminal charges.
content: Mayor Eric Adams placed limits for the first time on Wednesday on how migrants arrive in New York, pushing back against continuing efforts by the governor of Texas to send tens of thousands of asylum seekers to the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Lee Sun-kyun, ‘Parasite’ Actor, Found Dead at 48
description: Mr. Lee, a familiar face on Korean television and movie screens, rose to international fame after starring in the Oscar-winning film.
content: Lee Sun-kyun, the award-winning South Korean actor who rose to international fame after starring in the Oscar-winning film “Parasite,” was found dead in Seoul on Wednesday. He was 48.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh
title: JN.1 Now Accounts for Nearly Half of U.S. Covid Cases
description: Here’s what to know about the coronavirus variant, which was first detected in the United States in September.
content: As the holiday season winds down and Covid-19 cases start to pick up, a variant called JN.1 has now become the most common strain of the virus spreading across the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tacey Rychter
title: The 8 Most-Read Travel Stories of 2023
description: A golden retriever convention, flight etiquette rules and great walks from around the world: Here’s what readers loved this year.
content: Another year in travel, another 12 months of meltdowns and debacles. As one analyst put it, 2023 “took chaos to a new level.” Yikes. Still, travelers kept flying, including in record-breaking numbers on Thanksgiving weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Michigan Court Decides Trump Can Stay on the Ballot
description: Plus, what a crab museum has to teach us.
content: The Michigan Supreme Court upheld an appeals court decision that found that Donald Trump could appear on the ballot despite questions about his eligibility to hold elected office because of his attempts to overturn the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 27, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Dec. 27, 2023.
content: An article on Sunday about the rise of net migration to Britain since its exit from the European Union incorrectly described the role of the Conservative Party in the Brexit campaign. It was the party’s Brexit-supporting lawmakers, including the current prime minister, who played on fears of a foreign influx, not the entire Conservative Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Vivek Ramaswamy Stops TV Ad Spending
description: The campaign’s abrupt shift, focusing on other voter outreach efforts, reflects a significant change in strategy less than three weeks before the Iowa caucuses.
content: Vivek Ramaswamy, the wealthy entrepreneur seeking the Republican Party’s presidential nomination, has stopped spending money on cable television ads, a campaign representative said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By the staff of The Morning
title: Innovative Storytelling From 2023
description: We highlight some standout journalism from this year.
content: The Times is a newspaper, but it’s not only a newspaper. As a reader of this newsletter, you get the news in your email inbox every morning, not just on your doorstep. You might also listen to our journalism on a podcast app. You might watch it on TikTok.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan O'Callaghan
title: The First Secret Asteroid Mission Won’t Be the Last
description: AstroForge, a private company, wants to mine a space rock, but it doesn’t want the competition to find out which one.
content: For generations, Western space missions have largely occurred out in the open. We knew where they were going, why they were going there and what they planned to do. But the world is on the verge of a new era in which private interests override such openness, with big money potentially on the line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Video Games Let Them Choose a Role. Their Transgender Identities Flourished.
description: Transgender people have turned to games, some with robust character creators, as places where they can safely express themselves.
content: Nearly a decade before Anna Anthropy came out as a transgender woman, she was wearing a dress in the world of Animal Crossing on the Nintendo GameCube, leaving virtual bread crumbs for her family about information she was not prepared to share as a teenager.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Prosecutors Ask Judge to Keep Trump From Making ‘Baseless Political Claims’ in Trial
description: The special counsel, Jack Smith, is seeking to shape the evidence the jury in the federal election interference case will hear.
content: Federal prosecutors asked a judge on Wednesday to keep former President Donald J. Trump and his lawyers from claiming to the jury in his upcoming election interference trial that the case had been brought against him as a partisan attack by the Biden administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aruna D'Souza
title: Two Watershed Shows About 1993 Help Make Sense of 2023
description: A blue-chip gallery asks, does the infamous Whitney Biennial or “The Theater of Refusal” measure up 30 years later, when artists of color have moved to the mainstream?
content: A lot happened in the early 1990s: In about four years, the world saw the dissolution of the Soviet Union, the fall of the Berlin Wall, the Gulf War, a bombing of the World Trade Center, the beating of Rodney King and the riots that roiled Los Angeles, a peak in the AIDS crisis, a market crash, and the withdrawal of funding of controversial artists by the National Endowment of the Arts as part of a larger culture war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Eiffel Tower Closes for Labor Action on Creator’s Anniversary
description: Tourists could not ascend the tower on Wednesday, the 100th anniversary of the death of Gustave Eiffel, the civil engineer after whom it was named.
content: History lovers visiting Paris might have made a plan to check out the Eiffel Tower on Wednesday. After all, it was the 100th anniversary of the death of Gustave Eiffel, the eponymous civil engineer whose company designed and built it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: The Virtues of Inauthenticity
description: The historically inaccurate speech in “The Gilded Age” is as it should be.
content: My partner and I were eager to take in the ancient Greek sculptures at the Metropolitan Museum of Art that have been restored with the painted colors they would have had when new. The Greek sculptors adorned their work with vibrant colors that wore off over time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrea Orejarena, Caleb Stein, Kelly Weinersmith and Zach Weinersmith
title: The Beautiful Desolation of Life on Mars — On Earth
description: To live on the red planet, humans will need to bring along small reminders of home.
content: In May 1996, an autonomous resupply vehicle docked with Russia’s ailing Mir space station. It carried the usual items — food, clothes, scientific equipment — along with much more cherished ones. The American astronaut Shannon Lucid received M&Ms. For the two cosmonauts, Yuri Usachev and Yuri Onufriyenko, there were perfume-scented letters offering a welcome respite from the smells of the space station, which astronauts have likened to body odor, trash and hot metal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong, Julian E. Barnes, Muyi Xiao and Chris Buckley
title: Chinese Spy Agency Rising to Challenge the C.I.A.
description: The ambitious Ministry of State Security is deploying A.I. and other advanced technology to go toe-to-toe with the United States, even as the two nations try to pilfer each other’s scientific secrets.
content: The Chinese spies wanted more. In meetings during the pandemic with Chinese technology contractors, they complained that surveillance cameras tracking foreign diplomats, military officers and intelligence operatives in Beijing’s embassy district fell short of their needs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serge Schmemann
title: Ukraine Doesn’t Need All Its Territory to Defeat Putin
description: Putin is not trustworthy, but if he turns out to be serious, Ukraine should not pass up an opportunity to end the bloodshed.
content: The new report in The New York Times that Russia is quietly signaling a readiness to freeze the war in Ukraine is both suspicious and tantalizing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan and Jill Cowan
title: Pro-Palestinian Protests Block Traffic at New York and L.A. Airports
description: Dozens of demonstrators were arrested after blocking roadways outside Kennedy and Los Angeles International Airports on a busy holiday travel day.
content: More than two dozen pro-Palestinian protesters were arrested Wednesday morning after they blocked traffic heading to Kennedy International Airport in New York City during one of the busiest travel weeks of the year, according to the Port Authority Police Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Bandannas and Braids: In Praise of Willie Nelson’s Sense of Style
description: The Texas troubadour, who is having a moment at age 90, found success only after he decided to be fully himself, in his music and his look.
content: “Roll me up and smoke me when I die,” Willie Nelson sang from the stage of the Hollywood Bowl during his 90th birthday celebration in April.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Matt Damon, Fran Drescher and an Indian Soybean Farmer on 2024
description: I asked an array of people what they’re wishing for in the new year.
content: What are your hopes for 2024? See how they compare with those of 11 people I put that question to. (Most of them replied by email. The people from Afghanistan and India spoke by phone.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Images of Watermelons Signal Support for Palestinians
description: The fruit has taken on new prominence since the beginning of the Israel-Hamas war.
content: On and off social media, watermelons are being used as a symbol to communicate solidarity with Palestinians in the deadly war between Israel and Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Sing in Me, Chatbot …’
description: What happens to literature when writers embrace A.I. as their muse?
content: The robots of literature and movies usually present either an existential danger or an erotic frisson. Those who don’t follow in the melancholy footsteps of Frankenstein’s misunderstood monster march in line with the murderous HAL 9000 from “2001: A Space Odyssey,” unless they echo the siren songs of sexualized androids like the ones played by Sean Young in “Blade Runner” and Alicia Vikander in “Ex Machina.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall, Oleksandr Chubko, Cora Engelbrecht and Daniel Berehulak
title: Ukraine’s Stolen Children
description: Thousands of young Ukrainians were separated from their parents by the Russian authorities in the early stages of the war. They are among the most forlorn victims of the invasion.
content: Thousands of young Ukrainians were separated from their parents by the Russian authorities in the early stages of the war. They are among the most forlorn victims of the invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Perling
title: The Best Nonalcoholic Drinks
description: Many of these taste great just over ice.
content: Many of these taste great just over ice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Trump at the Supreme Court
description: The country’s top court will have at least three opportunities to weigh in on former President Donald J. Trump’s legal troubles.
content: The country’s top court will have at least three opportunities to weigh in on former President Donald J. Trump’s legal troubles.
source.name: The New York Times
